Posts.Content: Hi All Yes Letrozole were a bit dreadful for me too. Made the joints in my feet ache and I was hobbling around in the morning like a 90 year old. My oncologist changed me to Exemestane and \i have to say , it is a lot better . Maybe it would be worth asking about this? I was actually on the point of just not taking letrozole - it was so depressing. Cheers
Posts.Title: Letrozole are dreadful

Posts.Content: Wow! , it is amazing. I know cats live in a world of smell ( didnt know sheep did ) and i have heard that animals can be useful with detecting chemical changes - like epilepsy but fancy your cat doing that. Yes, take note if she does it again though of course she may have just got to like the bed.  The smell and taste thing is very weird. Mine went odd in hospital while i was having reconstruction but i guess it was the anaesthetic and the weird microwaved food.  Cigerette smoke not too bad for me - slight pangs sometimes as an ex smoker - but the smell of fag smoke on peoples clothes is awful. My hospital driver smokes and i can tell instantly someone gets in the car if they are a smoker or not. Many of them are - its almost like smoking makes you ill......maybe i should tell someone haha I guess we are all a mass of chemicals and cancer, treatment and things like stress just alter it and make us react in different ways. Maybe the cat was trying to figure it out or thought you needed help. Maybe there is something in me that is picking up a burning smell unrelated to cigarettes. I wonder if we understood it more whether it could help?
Posts.Title: Weird sense of smell ?

Posts.Content: Interesting....i keep getting this weird burnt smell and it only occured to me today that it is me not really there haha
Posts.Title: Weird sense of smell ?

Posts.Content: Hi all Just a note of warning.....I couldnt wait to get back to running ( finished chemo in june) and it felt great. But I went at it too intensly and now have a stress fracture in foot. Probably something to do with bone thinning effect as well. So am hobbling about on crutches and am really cross about it. So, slow and steady, little by little. Apparently stress fractures really common in people who increase activity levels quickly. According to advice online from Boots, you should only increase activity by bout 10% a weeek.
Posts.Title: Exercising after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Always Baking Guess only advice is don't panic , it will pass and you will feel better. I had 4 cycles of that drug and was very fatigued so juzt go with it and drink plenty of water and eat what you fancy. It kicked in for me on day3 following treatment. Bedford69 will increase the swimming i think. Sounds good. Glad its helped. But i love running and would like to get back to it in few months. Nothing like it and other types of exercise just not the same.
Posts.Title: Exercising after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Jen Don,t know about anyone else but I have never had any pain whatsoever with my 2 bouts of breast cancer. Get it checked out and you may find its not as bad as you think. Even if it as bad as you think it probably wont be....if you see what I mean. Try not to worry and do keep us posted Jane x
Posts.Title: Lump in my armpit.

Posts.Content: I thought she was really annoying and being dramatic and precious to make a story out of it. The sticky hair thing was over priced and grisly and fasting during chemo....come on! As if anyone sane would want to do that. I have been so hungry. It seems totaly the wrong thing to do.  I often get cross at the guardian ans the middle class superior people in london  telling the rest of us how to do things. I have been using the cold cap and itnis working pretty well. Thinned a bit but at least its my own hair not a bunch of skint strangers hair on my head stuck on with sellotape.  How much did that woman charge her !!!!!! Seems a total rip off.
Posts.Title: Decca Aitkenhead in the Guardian

Posts.Content: Yes, the goodie bag is a lovely idea. And as Helsbels says, the aftermath - the days following the chemo are more difficult really because you can feel so fatigued.  Hope it all goes well in the week. Your daughter will be pleased to get this first one over , as no doubt you will be too.  Xxxjane
Posts.Title: Daughters 1st chemo

Posts.Content: Hi there I can understand yr daughter going it alone. It is a long and boring day and not tbat pleasant. I went alone for first one but what worked for me was people coming in for the subsequent sessions - like for a few hours in the afternoon and then taking me home. You might find that works for yr daughter - maybe for next time. The cold cap adds time and makes it harder but it is worth it in my opinion. It is fine after the first 20 minutes. Foodwise - they do keep offering drinks and snacks at chemo....personally i felt ok during it but it does depend on what yr drugs are. I got side effects a few days after and  then had weird fancies....most drastically cravings for chinese takeaway but again i guess it depends on the drugs. I really hate fuss so just wanted to get with it alone. Sometimes youve just got to do whats best for you.....i reallt appreciated neing looked after once i got home though. Expect your daughter will feel the same Good luck
Posts.Title: Daughters 1st chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Best thing I took was my kindle. I downloaded some vera stanhope novels ( ann cleeves) treating myself to something I really wanted to read. I was in for week and really enjoyed the escapism.  The new dressing gown was nice too. People said to take various things but for me these were most important Good luck
Posts.Title: What to take to hospital?

Posts.Content: Hi all, Hi Silvercloud I didnt really think that there was much difference statistically in my case between having chemo and not having chemo either so I get what you say.. However my oncologist seemed to think that I should go for it, and on that basis mainly I am doing it now.   I mean it is hard enough having to go through this anyway without having to make these sorts of choices. (grumble mode)  Dont know about you but if I get a mechanic in to fix the car , the mechanic should know how to do it, not give me options. I just want the car to be fixed hopefully in a way that will last for a while. I can't see why the medical lot can't do the same. Make the choice based on the training and the evidence. Not leave it up to people who have to go from 0 to 60 in a medical learning curve.... I dont think these oncologists should play around like this. They ought to know what they are doing. They are trained. They should be able to make an informed decision about what is best, based on what we tell them.  Now, I am having this chemo and it is pretty dreadful and all along I'm thinking, so did I really need this anyway? Why did he recommend it? And in a way it is making it all a lot worse. That said, it will pass and am sure I will recover and I don't want to make a fuss. But this stuff obviously is not good for you. At the end of the day I could not go against the advice so went with it.... as LondonLass says there is no right or wrong answer....all the best to you too by the way...and to all of us....
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Mmmmm chips and gravy......suddenly that sounds like a winning combination.....thanks for the thought x
Posts.Title: Preparation for chemo

Posts.Content: I am so hungry on chemo and am craving a specific chinese takeway ( egg fried rice, the pork balls sweet and sour and chow mein) i am craving fry ups, burgers and chips and to be honest i would have no problem eating this stuff if i could. However due to complicated reasons i am not in my own home but staying with extremely small and healthy cousins who dont eat ....and i am marooned in the middle of the countryside . It is actually quite awful. I usually have a varied and healthy diet and am easygoing if staying elsewhere but i cant make them understand that a bit of so called unhealthy food would be great for morale. The other day i was faced with cheese and ryvita for lunch....can you imagine anything more depressing ...and although i usually eat a lot of fruit i am not enjoying it now. Just makes the side effects worse.... Sorry, got onto a heart felt rant here but all i can say is just eat what you want and what your body tells you. Plenty of time to get back to normal. Plenty of time to count calories and all that....one thing i am mad on is green tea. I can recommend that. To me it tastes like ordinary tea but ordinary tea tastes sickly ( milk). In my opinion there is nothing worse than people telling you to eat stuff because it is good for you. I know it is meant kindly but i enjoy my food, like cooking i lived in france for years and am finding it all a bit depressing good positive mental attitude is important and food part of the cure! . Cheers
Posts.Title: Preparation for chemo

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn I love the idea of the food parcel but i have located the nearest Chinese takeaway so  i will do it tomorrow.  Am looking forward to it immensly.  I think it is also about not being in control and staying with relations....but mainly it is just about the food..haha
Posts.Title: Preparation for chemo

Posts.Content: Aw Vicky , that all sounds horrible. It is really weird about the appetite. Yes, i will be better prepared for the next bout.  I had no idea my cousin and her husband did not eat and of course i should have turned up with loads of stuff so it is my fault really.  It must be hard for you being a chef and not being able ti face food. I wonder when it is all over whether you will like different things? Probably best not to think about it right now.... No,  smoking is really horrible. I used to do it but cant understand why or why it seemed such a big deal to give up.... Anyway, good luck for tuesday, you know what to expect this time...if it is any consolation ..i found the recovery quicker after 2 than 1 so hopefully that will be the same for you.  Thanks for writing
Posts.Title: Preparation for chemo

Posts.Content: Stop panicking, It will all be fine. You shouldn't get any pain and in a few weeks you will be on the mend and back home again. Mind you I know how easy it is to say that. I was so nervous ( frightened) before my op - it is a big thing. But these people know what they are doing and will have done it before loads of times.  Luckily the rather dishy anesthetist told me that  1 - they would make sure I was out for the count and yes if I did start waking up they would know about it.I had read a horror story in the daily mail about a woman who woke up in an operation but apparently they don't use that sort of anaesthetic in a DIEP op. And 2 the fact that my throat felt that I couldn't breathe was just a stress reaction.  Once it is over the recovery begins. Long time since I have had to deal with small children but I do think it can be beneficial to have them understand that sometimes even mum needs a bit of help. So she will probably enjoy doing little things for you - even if it is only drawing you a picture or telling people to mind your boob.  x
Posts.Title: 5 days till surgery and starting to freak out...

Posts.Content: Ah, ok, never thought of repatration. Yes i suppose that would be useful. Will bear it in mind thanks.
Posts.Title: Travel insurance recommendations for Europe

Posts.Content: If you have your ehic card you are covered for the same basic health care as any citizen of the country you are visiting. Must admit i never bother with insurance in europe for thst reason.  That said, i am surprised at the prices you are all quoting. I had cancer 20 yrs ago ( it came back) and last time nobody would insure me. I wonder why its changed?  I wonder if it applies to outside europe?
Posts.Title: Travel insurance recommendations for Europe

Posts.Content: Hi All I'm really worried. Had a diep reconstruction in february and chemo throughout june and july. Everything is fine though I do feel very tired sometimes but i guess that is normal. But I am really worried now. My recon boob has become a bit tender under my arm and although it looks the same , it feels different. It feels artificial and seems to drag down and I am  more aware of it than i was. I have a routine mammogram next week so not much longer to wait but i am really worried.  I am currently despising myself and rightly so. I stupidly had a small period of smoking for 2 months ( end of october to last week and anything you think and say I already know) I thought i could control it to 1 occasionally but it escalated and  the next thing \I was buying them and hiding them away. Nobody knew about it. The lengths i have been to ,to conceal it and I'm glad it;s over now. My feeling is that I have now compromised my reconstruction.So it might be too late. What was I thinking of?  Of course it might not be that. I have been swimming a lot ( was on holiday last week) and did help push a very heavy man in a wheelchair. I also lifted cases etc. It does seem to have come on quite suddenly - following these activities.  Any advice please? Has anyone noticed the diep getting more noticeable after 6 months. It does seem to have dropped a bit. I thought i was an ex smoker for good but learned it only takes one....I am an ex smoker for good now but i am panicking it is too late.
Posts.Title: massive panic! please don't hate me.

Posts.Content: I had had most of them removed 20 years ago ( first time ) but apparently there were a few left in there and they removed them this time. I did do a lot more than usual...i always go OTT on exercise ( well anything really)  Thanks for your kind reply
Posts.Title: massive panic! please don't hate me.

Posts.Content: Thanks, doing it now....will keep you posted xxx
Posts.Title: massive panic! please don't hate me.

Posts.Content: Thanks all xxxx Well, I phoned BCN and she was lovely. Said it was quite normal to get some lumpiness after surgery and not to beat myself up too much over the fags. As long as I had stopped now. she felt that the smoking happened too long after the op to be a factor now.  Just pleased to have stopped again - that will get easier as well in a few days. Anyone is the same boat I recommend the Allan Carr book.  Anyway feel a lot better now. Do you know I had completely forgotten about breast care nurses so thanks for the suggestions.  I will have my mammagram next week as planned and my other appointments in the new year. Not as worried now. xxxxx
Posts.Title: massive panic! please don't hate me.

Posts.Content: Ha Avril That hiding it from people is pretty stressful too. I hated that but felt ashamed coz I didn't want people to worry. In the end it was me that worried.,  I know what you mean about the bar and the wine.   But I think it is more the idea of it all than the reality. As you say it may make you feel sick in reality but if it really was the next place , it would be as lovely as you picture it ! Will definitely join you.  Feeling better about it all today following the discussion with BCN and posting on here.
Posts.Title: massive panic! please don't hate me.

Posts.Content: Hi there Well it seems to me you have been thru a lot and now you have the worry of your husband so it is understandable. You must be wondering when will it ever end and get back to normal.... I  am just replying because i am wondering if you need some professional help with this. You know your moods are extreme yet you can't help it. I am close to someone who has depression and a lot of this is caused by chemical imbalances and physical reasons rather than circumstances. Of course life is difficult sometimes but we must be strong and i just wondered if it would help to actually see a profesional about this. Sometimes physcology or more likely sometimes medication can help. I know this probably sounds not what is expected.....go for a walk...dance like nobodys watching etc.....but although these things can help, you know all that already and it still isnt working. Good luck with it. Goood luck for your husband too.
Posts.Title: HELP! I'm turning into someone I don't know.
